the achieved value is lower than the target; this may be explained by high levels of pre-existing knowledge within targeted communities, due to the previous sessions delivered during the first phase of the project (2014-2017) and through other channels, such as national awareness raising sessions.
The qualitative research started in August 2019 completed by late December 2019. 12 focus group discussions were conducted with 102 members of Afghan Diaspora in Denmark, Germany and the Netherlands
12 monographies avail. As at 30 Nov. 2017, but with limited in-depth analysis, and no identification of groups at-risk of joining violent groups
All monographies analyze unresolved conflicts and identify most at-risk groups to join violent groups, and document their needs and perceptions to the required of attention

One qualitative report from Seefar:  "Navigating Mixed Messages Can diaspora-led communications reduce Afghans’ irregular migration risks?" and and one report from Results in Health on SBCC divided into two sub reports: "Social and Behaviour Change Communication: A Concept Note for the Afghan Diaspora Information Project" and "Social and behaviour change communication (SBCC) approaches to address COVID-19 in Afghanistan"
